Throwback to one of the first batches of mushrooms! They remain a firm favourite to make and to sell.
March will be a busy month! Would love to see your faces at these events.
This vase and I have been on a journey... It's taken a while to get the glaze how I imagined it, but now I'm super happy with it.
Anyone else kinda obsessed with cashews? I could easily eat a whole bag in one go, but luckily these snacks bowls are great for stopping me do that.

Definitely not the hardest, most challenging or complicated thing I've made this past year, but one of the happiest surprises. I love how the glaze on this mushroom plant friend came out. 
Now if I could only remember which glazes I used.... 🤷🏻‍♀️🤦🏻‍♀️

.

One of @timeoutlondon top ten London markets, Canopy Market takes place in the covered area of the West Handyside Canopy at King’s Cross just behind @queerbritain and next to @csm_news

Fri: 12pm-8pm
Sat-Sun: 11am-6pm

BRING JOY SHOP SMALL this Christmas!

Adding water to the broken up bowl to rehydrate  the clay so it can become a new piece. 🔊 Volume up for the hissing and sizzling sounds of water being absorbed by the bone dry clay.

Luckily unfired clay can be endlessly recycled.

Starting the year off with reclaiming clay that's been marinating over the holidays. 
I keep all the water used for throwing and soak the dried out trimmings to make clay that can be turned into new pots. The clay slurry seen here is being dried on plaster bats for a while until it's firm enough to we wedged and I ended to rove air bubbles. Then it's ready to become new work.

It's always fascinating to me which glazes are the most popular on a given day at a market. Taking this past weekend as an example, it was a pretty even spread on Friday, my dark green drippy glaze was the most popular on Saturday and then this white speckled one was half the sales on Sunday. Why? Anyone have any ideas?
.
.
.

Mushrooms in the garden.
A fresh batch is waiting for glaze firing atm. I've been really enjoying making these, not only because they are new (and therefore exciting), but because they allow me to play around with glazes a lot more. I have a bunch of glaze test pots and little bottles of glaze I've inherited from different places that are too small for bigger pieces, but are perfect for these little shrooms.

In need of some new pottery? Next weekend we have the wonderful @pylon_ceramics trading with us back under the canopy, with their beautiful handmade pottery inspired by the flora of Hackney Marshes! ✨

Kat called her business Pylon ceramics because of the large transmission towers all throughout the marshes, utilitarian structures that both stand out and fit into the nature that surrounds them. All of her pieces are thrown on a potters wheel and decorated in a range of carefully selected glazes.

Kat hopes that you see the same combination of usefulness and beauty in her pieces, as she does in the electrical pylons of Hackney Marshes! Come and see her next weekend (16th - 18th) and find something special.

This one's fresh from the kiln and making me feel quite excited. I have also finally decided what to call this new glaze: eucalyptus. After lots of head scratching and all your suggestions, I felt it looked most like the beautifully blue-green leaves of eucalyptus gunii. And this pot is as round as it's leaves. 
Pot is coming to @canopy_market @realfoodfest in King's Cross tomorrow. 
.
.
.

Lots of cups and a handful of mugs were glazed on Tuesday and I'm about to go and unload the kiln now. 🤞🏻 Hope it was a good glaze firing! 
All that turned out nice will be coming to @canopy_market @realfoodfest this weekend, Fri - Mon. 
These pieces here have been fired once. After that I give them a light sanding to remove any burrs or sharp corners before glazing and firing them again. I love their blush pink colour at this stage. 
.
.
.
